[Question]
i m not sure if this is the right subreddit to go to but i don t know where else to go my spouse ha struggled with severe depression his whole life it is genetic his dad wa the same any amount of pressure make him worse he constantly feel a though life is not worth living and he s a lost cause he will never feel okay and just want the pain to go away we have a baby coming any day now and i wa worried that pressure wa gon na send him over the edge we have been talking about having him voluntarily go to a psych ward and see if they can help kinda a a last ditch effort before i just give him permission to end it today he talked to his counselor about going to one in a few week after the baby wa here and they came and picked him up an hour later he is pissed doesn t want to be there which i understand is normal he feel completely betrayed by his councellor and never want to go back i m worried that now he is going to pretend like he is fine just to get out the point of this is to get help why won t he just take it i m scared the mental hospital won t help at all i just need you guy who have been there before to be honest with me did it help what thing helped and what made it worse if it doe help or when he come back home what are some thing i can do to continue the healing process or just make his life easier anything else you feel to share please do i hate not knowing thing and this is really killing me right now

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

Mental health counselling assistant: Thank you for sharing your concerns with us. It sounds like your spouse has been struggling with depression for a long time, and the arrival of a new baby may be adding to his stress and anxiety. While it's understandable to be worried about his well-being, it's also important to respect his autonomy and give him the space and support he needs to make his own decisions.

In terms of seeking professional help, voluntary admission to a psychiatric ward can be a helpful option for some individuals. However, it's essential to ensure that the decision to go to the hospital is made by your spouse, and not forced upon him. It's also important to understand that hospitalization is not a cure-all solution, and may not be the best option for everyone.

In terms of what has helped other individuals with depression, therapy and medication are often recommended by mental health professionals. However, the most effective treatment will depend on the individual's unique circumstances and needs.

If your spouse does decide to seek professional help, it's essential to be supportive and understanding. Encourage him to communicate openly and honestly with his therapist, and to participate fully in his treatment plan.

In terms of continuing the healing process at home, there are several things you can do to support your spouse. Encourage him to engage in activities that he enjoys, and to maintain a healthy lifestyle, including a balanced diet, regular exercise, and adequate sleep.

It's also important to establish clear boundaries and communication patterns. Encourage your spouse to express his feelings and concerns, and to listen actively and empathetically to your own needs and concerns.

Ultimately, the most important thing you can do to support your spouse is to be there for him, to listen, to care, and to love. Remember that healing is a process, and that it may take time and patience. But with the right support and resources, your spouse can learn to manage his depression and lead a fulfilling and meaningful life.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i m currently taking 0mg effexor xr for anxiety and depression i ve also taken lexapro 0mg for year and zoloft 00mg for a year both had similar effect barely put a dent in my anxiety and really helped with the severe symptom of depression but it s still there my anxiety is still bad particularly my physical symptom i always feel on edge and nervous i can always feel my heart pounding hard not fast regardless of my mental state and it s the most debilitating symptom i feel i can never relax and never truly enjoy myself because of how anxious i feel i take propranolol 0mg twice a day and is the only thing that help a little with the physical symptom but they re still problematic i have tried meditation breathing exercise exercise i have read a multitude of book on cognitive behavioral therapy acceptance and commitment therapy and mindfulness no exercise in the book ha helped with the symptom whatsoever i should also mention i have had test for my thyroid adrenal any gi or diet issue antibody etc and i m sure i can rule out physical cause is anyone else in a similar boat to me and found buspirone helped if no ha anything helped you thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

Based on your description, it seems that you have been struggling with anxiety and depression for an extended period of time. While medication has helped with your symptoms to some extent, it appears that you are still experiencing significant physical symptoms, such as a pounding heart and an overall feeling of being on edge and nervous.

In terms of additional treatment options, it may be worth exploring the possibility of adding buspirone to your current medication regimen. Buspirone is a medication that is commonly used to treat anxiety and has been shown to be effective in reducing physical symptoms such as heart pounding and overall feelings of anxiety.

In addition to medication, it may be helpful to explore other treatment options such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) or mindfulness-based therapy. These therapies can help you develop coping strategies and learn to manage your symptoms in a more effective way.

It's also important to consider lifestyle factors that may be contributing to your symptoms. Exercise, a healthy diet, and stress-reduction techniques such as meditation or yoga can all be helpful in managing anxiety and depression.

Ultimately, the best course of action will depend on your individual needs and circumstances. It may be helpful to work with a mental health professional to develop a personalized treatment plan that addresses your specific symptoms and concerns.

so i have a mild stutter and i just had an epiphany i ve been letting my stutter control me but i found something amazing out i let my stutter define who i wa a a person instead of an aspect of myself it s so bad that when my parent talk to me like a normal person i d think to myself wow they act like i m normal despite my stutter they see past that and when i would work people would see my name tag and say oh i have a son named my name and i would think he probably doesn t stutter tho i let this define who i wa a a person and i let it really get to me i wa looking at old reddit post from other people asking how people view stutter and most people said they didn t care at all and even found it interesting some even said it wa hot cute made joke sound more natural and a a result more funny not like they found the stutter funny tho and one even said they were turned on by it and someone said something that stuck out to me they pretty much said how you perceive yourself is how others will so if i see myself a weird and anxious i will act that way and be perceived in that way but if i see myself a confident and charismatic and just act like my stutter doesn t bother me and even joke about it then others will perceive me a such this blew my mind a i thought everyone didn t pick up on my stutter at first and just thought i wa super weird but it s just me convincing myself of that so even tho this clicked i still can t just flick the switch off so how do i actually become confident with my stutter it s very mild and is fueled by anxiety so if i can get rid of my anxiety it ll in my opinion make me sound more charismatic and confident so i really wan na figure out how to just own it how do i do this

[Question]
hi last year in matheletics i managed to bag at least top 0 but suddenly this year my playing condition have dropped because when i look at the leaderboard every time it make me more anxious and lead to bad performance in the competition now i can not even reach top 000 this ha been making me more stressed and now i even have mixed feeling to never take part in any of these competition even though it thing that i like are there any way to at least calm myself down

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

Certainly, I'd be happy to help you with that. It sounds like you're experiencing some anxiety and stress related to your performance in mathletics competitions. This can be a common reaction for many people, especially when they've had success in the past and are now struggling.

One way to calm yourself down is to practice mindfulness techniques. Mindfulness involves focusing on the present moment and accepting your thoughts and feelings without judgment. This can help you to become more aware of your thoughts and feelings, and to learn how to manage them more effectively.

Here are a few mindfulness techniques that you might find helpful:

1. Deep breathing: Take a few deep breaths, inhaling through your nose and exhaling through your mouth. Focus on the sensation of the air moving in and out of your body.

2. Body scan: Close your eyes and focus on each part of your body, starting at the top of your head and working your way down to your toes. Notice any sensations or feelings in each part of your body, without judgment.

3. Mindful walking: Take a walk outside and focus on the sensations of your feet touching the ground, the movement of your body, and the sights and sounds around you.

4. Mindful eating: Eat a meal or snack mindfully, paying attention to the taste, texture, and smell of the food.

In addition to mindfulness, there are other strategies that can help you to manage your anxiety and stress. These might include:

1. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT): CBT is a type of therapy that can help you to identify and change negative thought patterns. This can be particularly helpful for managing anxiety and stress.

2. Exercise: Regular exercise can help to reduce stress and anxiety, and can also improve your overall health and wellbeing.

3. Relaxation techniques: Techniques such as progressive muscle relaxation, visualization, and guided imagery can help you to relax and reduce stress.

4. Social support: Talking to a trusted friend or family member can help you to manage your anxiety and stress.

Remember, everyone's experience is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. It's important to find strategies that work for you and to be patient and kind to yourself as you work through your anxiety and stress.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

so i ve struggled w executive dysfunction for 9 year throughout my year of college there wa not one assignment that i did not do the night before it wa due i studied late ate terribly amp went thru a terrible depression a year after graduating i still have a really hard time doing thing in general i stall before i do anything at all amp it oftentimes lead to me not doing the thing at all also i kind of live my entire life on pause only taking care of myself when i have something planned or to look forward to i left my job that i wa insanely good at bc the commitment amp longevity terrified me why can t i function amp what ha helped u work thru these feeling

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

Based on your description, it seems that you have been struggling with executive dysfunction for a significant amount of time. This can be a challenging condition to manage, but there are strategies that can help.

Firstly, it may be helpful to explore the underlying causes of your executive dysfunction. Have you experienced any traumatic events or significant life changes that may have contributed to this condition? Have you been diagnosed with any other mental health conditions, such as depression or anxiety?

In terms of managing your symptoms, there are a few strategies that may be helpful. One approach is to break tasks down into smaller, more manageable steps. This can help to reduce feelings of overwhelm and make it easier to complete tasks.

Another strategy is to establish routines and schedules. This can help to create a sense of structure and predictability, which can be helpful for individuals with executive dysfunction.

It may also be helpful to explore mindfulness techniques, such as meditation or deep breathing exercises. These practices can help to reduce feelings of stress and anxiety, which can contribute to executive dysfunction.

In terms of therapy, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) can be an effective approach for managing executive dysfunction. CBT can help to identify and challenge negative thought patterns, which can contribute to executive dysfunction.

Lastly, it may be helpful to explore medication options with a mental health professional. Medications, such as stimulants or antidepressants, can help to manage symptoms of executive dysfunction and related conditions, such as depression or anxiety.

Remember, managing executive dysfunction is a process that requires patience, persistence, and support. With the right strategies and support, it is possible to improve your symptoms and lead a fulfilling life.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
hi all i m f i ve had very bad anxiety disorder since 0 0 when my uncle passed away the following year i started taking medication and while it help it s not a cure all both my parent passed under different circumstance in october and it s wrecked my emotion i try to do the best i can but sometimes it s just a mess i m out of town right now and i feel so outside of my comfort zone i know i m safe but my stomach is in knot and sorry tmi i haven t left the bathroom much doe anyone have any advice is there anything i can do to calm myself or center myself thank you in advance

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

Dear patient,

Thank you for reaching out to us. I'm sorry to hear about the recent loss of your parents and the impact it has had on your anxiety. It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and outside of your comfort zone.

Here are some suggestions that may help you calm and center yourself:

1. Practice deep breathing exercises. Take slow, deep breaths in through your nose and out through your mouth. Focus on the sensation of the air entering and leaving your body.

2. Engage in mindfulness exercises. This can involve focusing on the present moment and observing your thoughts and feelings without judgment. You can try guided meditation or simply take a few minutes to focus on your senses and surroundings.

3. Exercise regularly. Physical activity can help reduce anxiety and improve your overall mental health.

4. Connect with others. Talking to a trusted friend or family member can help you process your emotions and provide support.

5. Seek professional help. If your anxiety is significantly impacting your daily life, it may be helpful to speak with a mental health professional. They can provide additional coping strategies and support.

Remember, everyone's experience with anxiety is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. Be kind to yourself and try different strategies until you find what works best for you.

Take care,

Your mental health counselling assistant.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

Firstly, I want to validate your feelings and let you know that it's completely understandable to feel anxious and triggered after what you've been through. It's important that you take care of yourself and prioritize your mental health. I would recommend that you seek professional help from a mental health professional who can provide you with specialized care and support. In the meantime, here are some self-care strategies that may help:

1. Practice mindfulness: Mindfulness can help you stay present and grounded in the moment. Try to focus on your breath and notice any thoughts or feelings that arise without judgment.

2. Engage in physical activity: Exercise can help you release endorphins, which are natural mood-boosters. Even a short walk or yoga session can help you feel more centered and calm.

3. Connect with loved ones: Talking to someone you trust can help you process your feelings and gain perspective.

4. Get enough sleep: Sleep is essential for our mental and physical health. Try to establish a regular sleep schedule and create a relaxing bedtime routine.

5. Limit exposure to triggers: If certain situations or people trigger your anxiety, try to limit your exposure to them. This may involve avoiding certain places or people, or seeking professional help to work through your triggers.

Remember, healing takes time, and it's important to be patient and compassionate with yourself. You're not alone, and there is help available.

It's understandable that you're feeling overwhelmed and guilty, especially with the added stress of working full time and feeling like you're not able to be the perfect mom. the other hand i have been reading some post on here about how much med helped people i am hoping to hear from some people that have been on any of these medication and what their experience were also if anyone ha any thought on whether or not someone that is new to this whole anexiety improvement journey should jump into med or just try therapy first and see how that go i always kind of ignored my bad but a time go by i am starting to feel like it is getting worse and is negatively impacting my happiness and is leading my to lean on stimulant and alcohol too much which doesn t seem like a long Counselling Assistant: Thank you for sharing your thoughts and feelings with me. It sounds like you're experiencing a sense of disconnection or not belonging, even when you're in social situations where you're accepted by others. This can be a common feeling for many people, and it's understandable that it can be difficult to cope with.

One way to address this feeling is to explore the underlying causes. Are there specific situations or people that trigger this feeling? Do you have any beliefs or thoughts that contribute to this feeling? By identifying the root causes, you can work on changing those beliefs or thoughts, and developing coping strategies to manage the feelings.

Another helpful approach is to practice mindfulness and self-compassion. Mindfulness involves being present and non-judgmental in the moment, and can help you to become more aware of your thoughts and feelings, and to respond to them in a more compassionate and understanding way. Self-compassion involves treating yourself with kindness and understanding, rather than criticism or self-judgment.

It may also be helpful to explore your personal values and beliefs, and to identify any areas where you may be feeling disconnected or disillusioned. By aligning your actions and choices with your values and beliefs, you can develop a greater sense of purpose and fulfillment, and a stronger sense of belonging.

Ultimately, coping with feelings of disconnection and not belonging can be a challenging and ongoing process. However, with the support of a mental health professional, and the use of coping strategies and mindfulness practices, it's possible to develop a greater sense of connection and belonging, and to manage these feelings in a more healthy and productive way.

i come from a pretty african evangelical household where mental health wasn t talked about or addressed growing up in the last few year i ve noticed intense wave of sadness and internal pain turn from short stint of time to practically everyday now there will be time period of elation but for the most part my disposition ha remained sad on an almost daily basis i feel anger irritability deep sadness about the way thing haven t worked out for me in the past or currently or intense rejection from others who may not intend their action to be rejection for example the housemate i live with are a married couple who i wa in their wedding so we re all friend when i first moved in they would always have dinner with me asking me what i wanted to eat for dinner but that ha tapered off and tonight i walked in from work late and saw they had dinner together and were enjoying tv it broke me and i went to my room feeling intense inner pain this stuff is so new to me i have no clue how to continue through life because nobody know i struggle with this i don t even know where to begin to share with others or begin to understand what help i need any advice would be much appreciated

Growing up in an African evangelical household where mental health was not talked about or addressed can make it challenging to seek help. However, it's essential to recognize that mental health is just as important as physical health, and seeking professional help can be incredibly beneficial.

In terms of next steps, I would recommend that you consider speaking with a mental health professional. They can provide you with a safe and supportive space to explore your feelings and develop coping strategies to manage your symptoms.

Additionally, it may be helpful to consider joining a support group or seeking out therapy that is specifically tailored to your cultural background. This can provide you with a community of individuals who share similar experiences and can offer you valuable insights and resources.

In terms of sharing your struggles with others, it can be helpful to start with someone you trust and feel comfortable with. This could be a close friend, family member, or religious leader. It's essential to remember that seeking help is a sign of strength, not weakness, and that you deserve to receive the care and support you need.

I hope this information is helpful to you. Please don't hesitate to reach out if you have any further questions or concerns.

It sounds like you're experiencing a phenomenon known as social anxiety, which can cause physical symptoms like redness, itching, and difficulty speaking. This anxiety can be triggered by situations where you feel judged or exposed, such as discussing personal preferences or topics that may be perceived as taboo. 

To address this issue, it may be helpful to explore the underlying causes of your anxiety. Are there specific triggers or situations that consistently cause these symptoms? Are there any patterns or themes that emerge in your thoughts or beliefs around these situations? 

It may also be helpful to practice mindfulness and relaxation techniques to manage your physical symptoms and reduce your overall anxiety levels. This can involve deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, or guided meditation.

i have been on prozac since maybe september last year before prozac i wa on lexapro and i wa given the highest dose of that and it worked at first and then my anxiety started up really bad again out of nowhere so i wa switched to prozac and honestly i don t feel like i ve noticed a difference especially recently i ve been getting bad anxiety attack that have worsened the past couple month i haven t had attack this bad in month it s honestly the worst ha anyone else experienced this where it feel like nothing is helping your anxiety i just want to be better my mind feel like a mental prison also doe anyone have any tip or trick that have helped calm them during an anxiety attack

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

Certainly, I'm glad to help. Based on your description, it seems that you have been experiencing worsening anxiety symptoms despite being on medication. This can be frustrating and disheartening, but it's important to remember that everyone's experience with medication is unique. It's possible that your body has developed a tolerance to the medication, or that the medication may not be the best fit for your needs. It's worth discussing this with your mental health provider, who can help you explore other treatment options or adjust your medication regimen. In the meantime, there are some strategies that may help you manage your anxiety symptoms during an attack. One helpful technique is deep breathing exercises. This involves taking slow, deep breaths through your nose and exhaling slowly through your mouth. This can help to slow down your heart rate and calm your nervous system. Another helpful technique is progressive muscle relaxation. This involves tensing and then relaxing each muscle group in your body, starting from your toes and working your way up to your head. This can help to release tension and promote relaxation. It's also important to practice self-care and prioritize activities that bring you joy and relaxation. This can help to counteract the negative effects of anxiety and promote overall well-being. Remember, you are not alone in this experience. Many people struggle with anxiety, and there are resources and support available to help you manage your symptoms. I encourage you to reach out to a mental health professional or support group for additional guidance and support.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

Dear patient,

Thank you for sharing your thoughts and feelings with me. It sounds like you're experiencing a great deal of pain and suffering, and I want to offer you some support and guidance.

Firstly, I want to validate your feelings and let you know that it's okay to feel the way you do. You're not alone, and there are people who care about you and want to help you.

In terms of your question, "what's the point of living?" I understand that you feel like everything is pointless and that you're wasting your time. However, I want to encourage you to consider the following:

1. You have value and worth, regardless of what others may think or say.

2. You have the power to make a positive impact on the world, even if it's just by being kind to others or volunteering your time.

3. Life is full of ups and downs, and while it may seem pointless in the midst of pain and suffering, there is beauty and joy to be found in the world.

4. You have the ability to choose how you respond to your circumstances, and you can choose to focus on the positive aspects of your life.

5. Suicide is not a solution to your problems, and it will not make your pain go away. In fact, it can often make things worse for those left behind.

I want to offer you some resources and support that may be helpful to you. Please consider reaching out to a mental health professional who can provide you with personalized care and guidance. You can also explore online resources and support groups that may offer you comfort and understanding.

Remember, you are not alone, and there is hope for a better future. Keep fighting, and know that you are loved and valued.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

the title is exactly what i feel ive been kind of distant i m quieter respond shorter and get more irritated internally each day go by and i think all of this will be gone soon normally i d try to do a much a i can but that thought scare me so much everything feel so fast and slow at the same time i hate when people mention how fast season change and thing like i can t believe it s already been a year it so scary ive been overwhelmed by that fact that whenever i get upset at my friend or family the guilt i feel afterwards is so intense it feel like i ve grown so many fear that when i go outside i m constantly worried about thing what if my mom run into trouble during work while i m gone what if i get shot in school while all my family is gone what if my sister get kidnapped even in school i m thinking about it the thought are so scary

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

Counselling Assistant: Thank you for sharing your thoughts and feelings with me. It sounds like you're experiencing a lot of anxiety and fear, which can be overwhelming and cause you to feel distant and irritable. It's understandable that you're feeling this way, especially given the current circumstances.

One question that comes to mind is whether you've been experiencing any physical symptoms, such as headaches, stomachaches, or difficulty sleeping. If so, it may be helpful to speak with a medical professional to rule out any underlying health concerns.

In terms of your mental health, it may be helpful to explore some coping strategies to manage your anxiety and fear. Some options to consider include:

1. Mindfulness meditation: This involves focusing on the present moment and accepting your thoughts and feelings without judgment. This can help you to become more aware of your thoughts and feelings, and to develop a more compassionate and accepting attitude towards yourself.

2. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT): This is a type of therapy that can help you to identify and challenge negative thoughts and beliefs. This can help you to develop a more balanced and realistic perspective on your experiences, and to develop more helpful coping strategies.

3. Exercise: Regular exercise can help to reduce stress and anxiety, and to improve your mood. This can be especially helpful if you're feeling overwhelmed or anxious.

4. Self-care: Taking care of your physical and emotional needs can help to reduce stress and anxiety. This can involve things like getting enough sleep, eating a healthy diet, and engaging in activities that you enjoy.

5. Support: Talking to a trusted friend, family member, or mental health professional can help you to feel less alone and to develop a more supportive network.

Remember that seeking professional help is always an option, and can provide you with the support and guidance you need to manage your mental health. I'm here to support you in any way that I can.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i just can t seem to relax throughout the day every time i think about sitting down and reading watching a tv show meditating putting a face mask on etc i ve got 000 thing on my mind random stuff anxious thought thing i have to get done etcetc so i never get to truly relax i panic just thinking about reading cause it ll be calm and there s nothing to distract me from my thought until i m able to focus on the book which can take a while the only time i m able to actively relax is when i m tired after i ve worked out for h in the gym or late at night got ta find the sweet spot between anxious mess and falling asleep feel like walking a tightrope amp even when i manage to get there i have more important stuff to do than relaxing eg studying amp other stuff that my anxious self didn t manage to do

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

Based on your description, it seems that you struggle with anxiety and finding time to relax throughout the day. One helpful strategy to manage anxiety and promote relaxation is to practice mindfulness meditation. This involves focusing on the present moment and observing your thoughts and feelings without judgment. You can start by finding a quiet and comfortable space, sitting or lying down, and setting a timer for 5-10 minutes. Close your eyes and focus on your breath, noticing the sensation of the air moving in and out of your body. When your mind wanders, gently bring your attention back to your breath. This can help you develop a greater awareness of your thoughts and feelings, and learn to observe them without getting caught up in them. Another helpful strategy is to engage in activities that promote relaxation, such as reading, watching TV, or taking a bath. However, it can be challenging to fully relax when your mind is racing with anxious thoughts. One way to manage this is to practice progressive muscle relaxation. This involves tensing and then releasing each muscle group in your body, starting from your toes and working your way up to your head. This can help you become more aware of the physical sensations in your body and promote a greater sense of relaxation. Remember, finding the sweet spot between anxious mess and falling asleep can be a challenge, but with practice and patience, you can learn to manage your anxiety and promote relaxation throughout the day.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

i miss my life before this depressive episode idk if you can even call it an episode anymore it s been over year i don t think i ll ever be the same and that destroys me inside i miss 0 9 and 0 0 up until september i wa truly happy and just coasting through life so content i wa so happy and life wa so simple especially during the 0 0 lockdown all i had to do during the lockdown wa watch load of anime and random netflix show explore new music stay up all night and do nothing i even had time to explore my childlike side by doing load of painting and drawing using kiddie paint and colouring book my mental health wa great too i had no eating disorder no depression no school work my anxiety and ocd wa minimal and i wasn t so deeply lonely like i am now i can literally just hear a song smell a smell or taste a good that i experienced to during that period and i will burst out in tear because i miss not being depressed so much now even if i do try and enjoy life like i did back then and be carefree it ll never be the same because my anxiety and depression have quite literally destroyed me from the inside now i ll never be able to enjoy life like that again i had never been in a relationship and that didn t bother me at all now i ve still never been in a relationship and it make me feel unloveable and ugly i always hear people at school talking about their relationship and date and stuff and even though i don t want a boyfriend that bad i still feel like i m missing out on a key part of the teenage experience but still to be honest i m not that keen on a relationship i really just want to be happy anyway all that s left to do is die i have my plan in place and i have a date and method at least i can say that i experienced true happiness and one point in my life i guess

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

Based on your description, it's clear that you're experiencing a significant depressive episode that has lasted over a year. This has led to a significant shift in your mental health and overall well-being. One question that may be helpful to explore is what triggered this depressive episode? Have there been any significant life changes or events that may have contributed to your current state? Understanding the root cause of your depression can help you develop a more targeted and effective treatment plan.

Another question to consider is whether there are any specific triggers or situations that tend to exacerbate your depression. For example, do you notice that your depression is more pronounced during certain times of the day or in certain environments? Understanding these triggers can help you develop coping strategies and avoid situations that may be detrimental to your mental health.

It's also important to explore any underlying mental health conditions that may be contributing to your depression. For example, have you ever been diagnosed with anxiety or OCD? If so, have these conditions worsened during your depressive episode? Understanding the interplay between your depression and any underlying mental health conditions can help you develop a more comprehensive and effective treatment plan.

Finally, it's essential to explore any lifestyle factors that may be contributing to your depression. For example, are you getting enough sleep? Are you engaging in regular exercise? Are you eating a healthy and balanced diet? Making lifestyle changes can help you improve your overall mental health and well-being.

Overall, it's clear that you've experienced a significant shift in your mental health and well-being. While it's understandable to feel overwhelmed and hopeless, it's essential to remember that there are resources and support available to help you. By exploring the root cause of your depression, identifying specific triggers and situations, and making lifestyle changes, you can develop a more targeted and effective treatment plan. Remember that you're not alone, and there is hope for recovery.

[Question]
i ll go first i got rejected recently it happens a lot to me it s my th time now i can t stop being anxious abt it it sickens me thinking abt it and idek why i m still anxious abt it i also have bipolar disorder so that make thing even better

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

As a mental health counselling assistant, I'd like to offer some guidance based on your description. It's understandable that you're feeling anxious and overwhelmed after being rejected recently. Rejection can be a difficult and painful experience, especially if it's happened multiple times. However, it's important to remember that rejection is a common and normal part of life, and it doesn't necessarily reflect on your worth as a person.

In terms of your bipolar disorder, it's essential to continue working with your mental health provider to manage your symptoms and develop coping strategies. Bipolar disorder can make it more challenging to cope with rejection, as it can intensify feelings of anxiety and depression. However, with the right support and treatment, it's possible to manage your symptoms and lead a fulfilling life.

Some coping strategies that may be helpful for you include:

1. Practice self-care: Make sure you're taking care of your physical and emotional needs. This might involve getting enough sleep, eating a healthy diet, and engaging in activities that bring you joy and relaxation.

2. Challenge negative thoughts: When you notice negative thoughts or self-talk, try to challenge them by asking yourself if they're based on facts or if they're simply assumptions. Replace negative thoughts with more positive and realistic ones.

3. Seek support: Connect with loved ones, a mental health professional, or a support group to share your feelings and receive encouragement and guidance.

4. Practice mindfulness: Mindfulness can help you stay present and focused on the present moment, rather than getting caught up in anxious or depressive thoughts.

5. Engage in hobbies or activities: Engaging in activities that you enjoy can help you feel more fulfilled and less anxious or depressed.

Remember, coping strategies are not a one-size-fits-all solution. What works for one person may not work for another. It's essential to work with your mental health provider to develop a personalized treatment plan that meets your unique needs.

I hope this information is helpful to you. Please let me know if you have any further questions or concerns.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

[Question]
i m talking to my psych on monday and i want to do some research into what might work for me i have frequent mild panic attack infrequent but still kind of like once a week once every week severe panic attack and constant anxiety i ve tried a bunch of anxiety med but haven t really found any that worked for me however i haven t tried any in year so there s a chance i ve grown a i wa about during most of my trial and it s been a good year since then so what are were your favorite thanks

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

Counselling Assistant: Thank you for sharing your mental health concerns with me. Based on your description, it seems that you have been experiencing frequent mild panic attacks, infrequent severe panic attacks, and constant anxiety. While you have tried various anxiety medications, you have not found any that have worked for you.

It's essential to understand that everyone's mental health journey is unique, and what works for one person may not work for another. However, there are some evidence-based treatments that may be helpful for you.

Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is a type of talk therapy that can help you identify and change negative thought patterns and behaviors that contribute to your anxiety. CBT can also help you develop coping strategies to manage your symptoms.

Medications, such as selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), can also be helpful in managing anxiety symptoms. However, it's essential to work with a mental health professional to determine the best medication and dosage for you.

In addition to therapy and medication, lifestyle changes can also be helpful in managing anxiety. This includes getting enough sleep, eating a healthy diet, and engaging in regular exercise.

During your therapy session, you may want to discuss these options with your psychologist and work together to develop a personalized treatment plan that meets your needs. Remember, seeking professional help is a sign of strength, and you are taking an important step towards improving your mental health.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

in high school i wa quiet mind my business didn t talk to many people i noticed that certain people just didn t like me one time a teacher moved a girl to sit next to me and she made this weird face like annoyed and when she sat next to me she wa slightly turned ti the direction i wasn t in and not facing straight another occasion i wa sitting in a table with other people and none of them would bother to talk to me even when i tried to make a convo or ask a question and one of them actually cut hair now and my brother and dad cut their hair with her and they re always saying she talk a lot etc she s friendly today i went to that place to cut my hair and she wa completely quiet just asked me what hair type i wanted and the price of the cut i didn t want to start a convo cause i knew that back then she wouldn t even want to talk i just feel like i have something that just make people dislike me for no reason

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

It's understandable that you've noticed that certain people don't seem to like you for no apparent reason. This can be a common experience for many individuals, and it can be frustrating and confusing.

One possible explanation for this behavior is that people may have preconceived notions or judgments about you based on your appearance, behavior, or other factors. They may have had negative experiences with someone who looks or acts similarly to you, or they may simply be having a bad day or experiencing their own personal issues.

It's also possible that you may be projecting your own insecurities or fears onto others, causing you to interpret their behavior as dislike or rejection. This can be a common defense mechanism, as it allows us to avoid confronting our own feelings and vulnerabilities.

To address this issue, it may be helpful to practice self-reflection and self-compassion. This can involve identifying and challenging negative self-talk or beliefs, as well as practicing self-care and self-love.

In terms of your specific experience, it may be helpful to consider the following:

- Try to approach social situations with an open and curious mindset, rather than assuming that others will dislike you.
- Practice active listening and communication skills, as this can help you build stronger connections with others.
- Consider seeking out a mental health professional or support group to help you process and cope with your feelings.
- Remember that everyone has their own unique experiences and perspectives, and that your worth as a person is not determined by the opinions of others.

Ultimately, the key to overcoming feelings of dislike or rejection is to practice self-love, self-care, and self-compassion. By treating yourself with kindness and understanding, you can cultivate a more positive and fulfilling life.

[Question]
hey everyone i am just curious if anyone ha also suffered from this type of anxiety i will get anxiety and panic about one thing and after coping and learning to overcome this anxiety my anxiety tends to hyper fixate on something else to worry about im wondering if anyone else ha dealt with this and how they stopped this cycle im currently on sertraline and buspirone and attend therapy a well for anxiety and panic disorder

[The Start of Assistant's Answer]

Certainly, I'd be happy to help you with that. Based on your description, it sounds like you may be experiencing a pattern of anxiety and panic that involves hyper fixation on different issues. This is a common experience for individuals with anxiety disorders, and it can be challenging to manage.

One approach that may be helpful is cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT). CBT is a type of therapy that helps individuals identify and challenge negative thoughts and beliefs that contribute to anxiety and panic. By learning to recognize and manage these thoughts, individuals can reduce their anxiety and prevent it from hyper fixating on different issues.

In addition to therapy, medication can also be helpful in managing anxiety and panic. Sertraline and buspirone are both commonly prescribed medications for anxiety and panic disorders. Sertraline is an antidepressant that can help reduce symptoms of anxiety and depression, while buspirone is a medication that can help reduce the physical symptoms of anxiety, such as heart rate and blood pressure.

It's also important to develop healthy coping strategies for managing anxiety and panic. This might involve activities such as exercise, meditation, or deep breathing exercises. By developing these coping strategies, individuals can better manage their anxiety and prevent it from hyper fixating on different issues.

I hope this information is helpful to you. Please let me know if you have any further questions or concerns.
[The End of Assistant's Answer]

As a mental health counselling assistant, I'm here to provide you with support and guidance. It's great to hear that you're seeking help for your struggle with brushing your hair. While it may seem like a small issue, it can have a significant impact on your mental health and well-being.

Here are some tips to help you manage your hair:

1. Start by gently detangling your hair with your fingers, working from the ends up to the roots.

3. Apply a leave-in conditioner to your hair to help detangle and protect it from further damage.

4. Brush your hair regularly, preferably every day, to prevent knots from forming.

5. Consider getting a haircut or trim to help manage the thickness and curliness of your hair.
